hints.content:
We can think of division as the following: 
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}=\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}}$

We know the $\color{green}\text{total}\color{black}$:There are $\color{green}20\color{black}$ flowers total.And we know the $\color{blue}\text{number of groups}\color{black}$:There are $\color{blue}4$ vases.

Let's put those numbers in the equation.
$\color{green}\text{ Total}\color{black}\div\color{blue}\text{ Number of groups}\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}\color{black}$
$\color{green}20\color{black}\div\color{blue}4\color{black}=\color{purple}\text{ Size of the groups}}$

The quotient will tell us the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$.In this problem, the $\color{purple}\text{size of the groups}\color{black}$ is the $\color{purple}\text{number of flowers in each vase}}$.
The quotient tells us the $\color{purple}\text{number of flowers in each vase}\color{black}$.

question.content: There are $20$ flowers. We want to divide them equally into $4$ vases. **What does the expression $20\div 4$ represent?**

options: Number of flowers in each vase
correctAnswers: Number of flowers in each vase

hints.content: The expression $\color{green}60\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$ can represent $\color{green}60\color{black}$ total items split evenly into groups of $\color{purple}6$.Which problem wants to split $\color{green}60\color{black}$ into groups of $\color{purple}6$?

###Millersburg bakeryWe want to find out how many bags of sugar are left, so we subtract $\color{green}60\color{black} - \color{maroon}6$.$\color{green}60\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###JewelerWe want to find out how many gems there are, so we add $\color{green}60\color{black} + \color{maroon}6$.$\color{green}60\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###BillyWe want to split the $\color{green}60\color{black}$ bikes evenly into groups of $\color{purple}6$. So, we divide $\color{green}60\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$.$\color{green}60\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$ helps us solve this problem

The expression $\color{green}60\color{black}\div\color{purple}6$ can solve the following context:- There are $60$ bikes parked in the bike racks at Billy's school. If there are $6$ bikes parked at each bike rack, how many bike racks are there?

options: There are $60$ bikes parked in the bike racks at Billy's school. If there are $6$ bikes parked at each bike rack, how many bike racks are there?
The Millersburg bakery had $60$ bags of sugar. They used $6$ bags of sugar to make some oatmeal cookies. How many bags of sugar are left?
A jeweler had $60$ gems. She bought $6$ more at an auction. How many gems does she have now?
correctAnswers: There are $60$ bikes parked in the bike racks at Billy's school. If there are $6$ bikes parked at each bike rack, how many bike racks are there?

hints.content: The expression $\color{green}63\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$ can represent $\color{green}63\color{black}$ total items split evenly into groups of $\color{purple}9$.Which problem wants to split $\color{green}63\color{black}$ into groups of $\color{purple}9$?

###JessicaWe want to find out how many pieces of pizza are left, so we subtract $\color{green}63\color{black} - \color{maroon}9$.$\color{green}63\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###TimWe want to find out how many scissors there are, so we add $\color{green}63\color{black} + \color{maroon}9$.$\color{green}63\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###TatsuWe want to split the $\color{green}63\color{black}$ lemons evenly into groups of $\color{purple}9$. So, we divide $\color{green}63\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$.$\color{green}63\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$ helps us solve this problem

The expression $\color{green}63\color{black}\div\color{purple}9$ can solve the following context:- Tatsu needs $9$ lemons to make a pitcher of lemonade. If Tatsu has $63$ lemons, how many pitchers of lemonade can he make?

options: Tatsu needs $9$ lemons to make a pitcher of lemonade. If Tatsu has $63$ lemons, how many pitchers of lemonade can he make?
There are $63$ scissors in the drawer. Tim placed $9$ more scissors in the drawer. How many scissors are there in total?
Jessica has $63$ pieces of pizza. She ate $9$ pieces with her friends. How many pieces of pizza does she have left?
correctAnswers: Tatsu needs $9$ lemons to make a pitcher of lemonade. If Tatsu has $63$ lemons, how many pitchers of lemonade can he make?

hints.content: The expression $\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ can represent $\color{green}64\color{black}$ total items split evenly into $\color{blue}8$ groups.Which problem wants to split $\color{green}64\color{black}$ into $\color{blue}8$ equal groups?

###MollyWe want to find out how many jellybeans are left, so we subtract $\color{green}64\color{black} - \color{maroon}8$.$\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###DarylWe want to find out how many pencils there are, so we multiply $\color{green}64\color{black} \times \color{maroon}8$.$\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

The expression $\color{green}64\color{black}\div\color{blue}8$ can solve the following context:- Marco has $64$ toy cars. He divides them into $8$ equal groups. How many cars are in each group?

hints.content: The expression $\color{green}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}3$ can represent $\color{green}27\color{black}$ total items split evenly into $\color{blue}3$ groups.Which problem wants to split $\color{green}27\color{black}$ into $\color{blue}3$ equal groups?

###GinoWe want to find out how many walnut trees are left, so we subtract $\color{green}27\color{black} - \color{maroon}3$.$\color{green}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}3$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###LaTashaWe want to split the $\color{green}27\color{black}$ stickers evenly onto $\color{blue}3$ pieces of paper.  So, we divide $\color{green}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}3$.$\color{green}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}3$ helps us solve this problem

The expression $\color{green}27\color{black}\div\color{blue}3$ can solve the following context:- LaTasha has $27$ rabbit stickers. She splits the stickers evenly among $3$ pieces of paper. How many stickers did LaTasha put on each piece of paper?

###StevenWe want to find out how many candy bars are left, so we subtract $\color{green}42\color{black} - \color{maroon}7$.$\color{green}42\color{black}\div\color{blue}7$ does **not** help us solve this problem.

###JulieWe want to find out how many jellybeans there are, so we multiply $\color{blue}7\color{black} \times \color{maroon}42\color{black}$.$\color{green}42\color{black}\div\color{blue}7$ does **not** help us solve this problem.
